questions.question: What is the value of <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: The cosine of <math><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi></math> radians is the same as the cosine of <math><mi>π</mi></math> radians, since <math><mn>7</mn><mi>π</mi> <mo>-</mo> <mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>π</mi></math>, and <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that cosine is periodic with period 2π, so reduce angles modulo 2π to find equivalent values in the unit circle.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='185' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='310' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='195' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><polyline points='200,140 210,140 210,150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Two radii, OA and OC, are drawn such that OA is horizontal to the right and OC is vertical upward, forming a 90-degree angle.
questions.question: The circle shown has center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math> and a circumference of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>24</mn></math>. What is the length of minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The central angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The length of an arc is proportional to the fraction of the circumference subtended by its central angle. The fraction is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>90</mn><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. Therefore, the length of minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' stroke='lightgray' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='185' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><text x='310' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='195' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><path d='M 300 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 200 50' stroke='red' stroke-width='4' fill='none' /><text x='220' y='100' font-size='14' fill='red'>1/4 Circumference</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The circle is shown with the minor arc AC highlighted in red. Text indicates that this arc represents 1/4 of the total circumference.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the length of an arc, calculate the fraction <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mi>angle</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac></math> and multiply it by the total circumference.

questions.question: The equation <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math> represents a circle in the xy-plane. What is the radius of this circle?
questions.explanation: The standard form is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo> <msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, so <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo> <mn>49</mn></math>, <math><mi>r</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the radius as the square root of the constant term in the standard circle equation.

questions.question: A circle has equation <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Which of the following is the center of the circle?
questions.explanation: The center is at <math><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math> where the equation is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo> <msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, so <math><mi>h</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mi>k</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The signs in the parentheses indicate the opposite for the center coordinates.

questions.question: A circle in the xy-plane has equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square for <math><mi>x</mi></math>: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, for <math><mi>y</mi></math>: <math><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Add to both sides: left <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, right <math><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn> <mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn> <mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. Radius <math><msqrt><mn>24</mn></msqrt></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the radius from a general equation, complete the square to convert to standard form.

questions.question: The number of radians in a 540-degree angle is <math><mi>a</mi><mi>π</mi></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math> is a constant. What is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Convert degrees to radians by multiplying by <math><mi>π</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>180</mn></math>: <math><mn>540</mn> <mo>×</mo> <mi>π</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>180</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, so <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the conversion factor π radians = 180 degrees to switch between units.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='185' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><circle cx='300' cy='150' r='4' fill='black' /><text x='310' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>P</text><circle cx='200' cy='50' r='4' fill='black' /><text x='195' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>Q</text><circle cx='100' cy='150' r='4' fill='black' /><text x='80' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>R</text><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='300' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='100' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Points P, Q, and R lie on the circumference. P is to the right, Q is at the top, and R is to the left.
questions.question: Points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>Q</mi></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>R</mi></math> lie on the circle shown. Minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> has length 8 and major arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> has length 24. What is the circumference of the circle?
questions.explanation: The circumference of a circle is the sum of the lengths of the minor arc and the major arc defined by the same two endpoints. Here, the minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> has length <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn></math> and the major arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> has length <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>24</mn></math>. Therefore, the total circumference is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' stroke='lightgray' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M 300 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 200 50' stroke='red' stroke-width='4' fill='none' /><text x='260' y='90' font-size='14' fill='red'>8</text><path d='M 200 50 A 100 100 0 1 0 300 150' stroke='blue' stroke-width='4' fill='none' /><text x='150' y='200' font-size='14' fill='blue'>24</text><text x='310' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>P</text><text x='195' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>Q</text><text x='200' y='155' font-size='12'>O</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The circle is split into two arcs connecting P and Q. The shorter (minor) arc is highlighted in red and labeled 8. The longer (major) arc is highlighted in blue and labeled 24. Together they complete the circle.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The minor arc and the major arc between two points make up the entire circle. To find the circumference, simply add their lengths together.

questions.question: An angle has a measure of <math><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi></math> radians. What is the measure of the angle in degrees?
questions.explanation: Multiply by <math><mn>180</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>π</mi></math>: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mi>π</mi> <mo>×</mo> <mn>180</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>π</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>×</mo><mn>180</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>75</mn></math> degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Convert radians to degrees by multiplying by 180/π.

questions.question: The equation of a circle is <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math>. What is the center of the circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></math>, <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></math>, center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The center is the point (h,k) after completing the square, with signs opposite to the linear terms.

questions.question: A circle has center at (4, -1) and radius 7. Which equation represents this circle?
questions.explanation: The standard form is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo> <msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, with <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Ensure the signs for the center are correct in the standard equation.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='400' viewBox='0 0 400 400' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='400' fill='white' /><defs><pattern id='grid' width='25' height='25' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 25 0 L 0 0 0 25' fill='none' stroke='lightgray' stroke-width='0.5'/></pattern></defs><rect width='400' height='400' fill='url(#grid)'/><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='400' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='0' y1='200' x2='400' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='200' cy='200' r='125' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='1.5' /><line x1='200' y1='200' x2='275' y2='100' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><circle cx='275' cy='100' r='5' fill='black' /><text x='285' y='100' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>T(3,4)</text><line x1='175' y1='25' x2='375' y2='175' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='380' y='215' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>x</text><text x='210' y='15' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>y</text><text x='185' y='215' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle centered at the origin (0,0) in the xy-plane. A radius connects the center to point T(3,4). A red tangent line passes through T, perpendicular to the radius.
questions.question: A circle has center at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Line <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>l</mi></math> is tangent to the circle at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Which point lies on line <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>l</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
1. **Find the slope of the radius:** The radius connects the center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> to the point of tangency <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Slope <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>.
2. **Find the slope of the tangent:** The tangent line is perpendicular to the radius. Slope <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
3. **Find the equation of the line:** Using point-slope form <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></math> with point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. This can be rewritten as <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, or <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>.
4. **Check the options:** Substitute <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math> into the equation: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>21</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. This is correct.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='400' viewBox='0 0 400 400' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='400' fill='white' /><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='400' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='0' y1='200' x2='400' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='200' x2='275' y2='100' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><line x1='175' y1='25' x2='375' y2='175' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='275' cy='100' r='5' fill='black' /><text x='285' y='90' font-size='14'>T(3,4)</text><circle cx='375' cy='175' r='5' fill='green' /><text x='320' y='195' font-size='14' fill='green' font-weight='bold'>(7,1)</text><path d='M 267 110 L 257 103 L 265 92' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' /><path d='M 275 100 L 375 100 L 375 175' fill='none' stroke='purple' stroke-dasharray='4' /><text x='325' y='90' font-size='12' fill='purple'>run = +4</text><text x='380' y='140' font-size='12' fill='purple'>drop = -3</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart illustrates the solution by plotting the point (7,1) on the red tangent line. A slope triangle (purple) is drawn from T(3,4) to the point (7,1) showing a run of 4 and a drop of 3, confirming the slope of -3/4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The tangent to a circle is always perpendicular to the radius at the point of tangency. If the radius has slope <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi></math>, the tangent has slope <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></math>.

questions.question: Points M and N lie on a circle with center P and radius 5. Triangle MP N has perimeter 17. What is the length of MN?
questions.explanation: MP = PN = <math><mn>5</mn></math>, perimeter <math><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>MN</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>, <math><mi>MN</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In a triangle with two radii, the sides are equal, so subtract twice the radius from perimeter to find the chord.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='80' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='290' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='160' y2='80.7' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='150' y='75' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>C</text><circle cx='240' cy='80.7' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='245' y='75' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>D</text><circle cx='160' cy='219.3' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='145' y='230' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='190' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><path d='M 230 150 A 30 30 0 0 0 215 124' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='215' y='135' font-size='12'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Points A and C lie on the circle, forming a central angle AOC labeled x°. Point D lies on the minor arc AC. Point B lies on the major arc AC.
questions.question: The circle has center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math>, the length of arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math>. What is the length of arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
The length of an arc is proportional to the central angle it subtends. 
1. **Analyze Arc ADC:** The central angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> corresponding to minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>120</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The length is given as <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
2. **Analyze Arc ABC:** Arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> represents the remainder of the circle (the major arc). Its central angle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>360</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>240</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
3. **Calculate Length:** The ratio of the angles is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>240</mn><mn>120</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Therefore, the length of arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is twice the length of arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. 
<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mtext>Length</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='80' stroke='lightgray' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M 280 150 A 80 80 0 0 0 160 80.7' stroke='red' stroke-width='4' fill='none' /><text x='220' y='60' font-size='14' fill='red'>4π (120°)</text><path d='M 160 80.7 A 80 80 0 1 0 280 150' stroke='blue' stroke-width='4' fill='none' /><text x='160' y='260' font-size='14' fill='blue'>? (240°)</text><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='3' fill='black' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='160' y2='80.7' stroke='black' /><text x='190' y='165' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='290' y='155' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='150' y='75' font-size='12'>C</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart highlights the minor arc ADC in red (labeled 4π, 120°) and the major arc ABC in blue (corresponding to 240°), visually demonstrating that the major arc is twice the length of the minor arc.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Arc lengths are directly proportional to their central angles. If the angle doubles, the arc length doubles.

questions.question: The graph of <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math> is a circle. What is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn> <mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn> <mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, radius <math><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Add the squares for completing the square to both sides to find the radius squared.

questions.question: The circle has equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. What is the radius?
questions.explanation: Complete the square: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>, <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>, radius <math><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check the calculations when completing the square for both x and y terms.

questions.question: A circle has center at ( -2,5) and passes through (1,9). What is the radius?
questions.explanation: The distance from center to point is <math><msqrt><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn></msqrt> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt><mn>25</mn></msqrt> <mo>=</mo> <mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the distance formula to find the radius when given center and a point on the circle.

questions.question: The points (2,3) and (8,11) are endpoints of a diameter of a circle. What is the equation of the circle?
questions.explanation: The center is the midpoint <math><mo>(</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo> <mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. The radius is half the diameter, diameter <math><msqrt><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt> <mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>36</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>64</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>100</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, half <math><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Find the center as the midpoint of the diameter and radius as half the diameter length.

questions.question: What is the area of a circle with arc length 10π for a 120-degree central angle? The area of the circle is <math><mi>a</mi><mi>π</mi></math>, find <math><mi>a</mi></math>.
questions.explanation: Arc length = <math><mo>(</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>360</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi> <mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, <math><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, <math><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>, area <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>225</mn><mi>π</mi></math>, so <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>225</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve for radius from arc length and angle, then compute area.

questions.question: Two circles intersect at points A and B. The centers are C and D, with CA =5, DA=5, CD=6. What is the length of AB?
questions.explanation: The two circles have equal radii <math><mn>5</mn></math>, distance between centers <math><mn>6</mn></math>. The line segment joining the centers bisects the common chord AB at right angles. Let M be the midpoint of AB. Then CM = <math><mn>6</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn></math>. In triangle CMA, CA=<math><mn>5</mn></math>, CM=<math><mn>3</mn></math>, so AM = <math><msqrt><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo> <msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt><mn>25</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>16</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Thus AB=<math><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the formula for the length of the common chord in intersecting circles using centers and radii.

questions.question: A circle has equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. What is the radius?
questions.explanation: Complete the square: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn><mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>49</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi> <mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn> <mo>=</mo> <mn>16</mn> <mo>+</mo><mn>49</mn> <mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn> <mo>=</mo><mn>81</mn></math>, <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>+</mo> <mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup> <mo>=</mo><mn>81</mn></math>, radius <math><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Double-check the addition when completing the square to get the correct r^2.
